Terminator 2: Judgment Day is not only one of the greatest sequels ever made but one of the greatest movies of all time. Released in 1991, directed by James Cameron, and starring Arnold Schwarzenegger, Linda Hamilton, and Edward Furlong, it is a masterpiece of science fiction and action that has stood the test of time.

The film is set in a future where machines have taken over the world and are trying to wipe out the remaining human resistance. In a desperate attempt to change the future, a reprogrammed Terminator model-101 (Schwarzenegger) is sent back in time to protect John Connor (Furlong), the future leader of the human resistance, from an advanced Terminator model T-1000 (Robert Patrick) sent to kill him and is almost infinitely more complex than the Terminator model-101. The T-1000 has the ability to imitate any human it touches, which makes it a way more formidable opponent giving the viewer a constant feeling of "Is that who we think it is?". This one aspect alone makes way for some groundbreaking storytelling and situations. Especially for the time it was released.

Terminator 2 is a perfect blend of action, suspense, and character development. The special effects, especially for their time, were amazing and still hold up well today! But what really sets this movie apart is its emotional depth. The relationship between John and the Terminator is a highlight of the film, as the machine learns to understand and care for humanity. The performances by Schwarzenegger, Hamilton, and Furlong are exceptional, adding depth and nuance to their characters.

The movie's themes are timeless and universal, exploring the nature of humanity, sacrifice, and the consequences of our actions. It is a thrilling and intense ride that never lets up, with some of the most iconic and memorable scenes in movie history, such as the chase on the freeway and the final showdown in the factory.

In conclusion, Terminator 2: Judgment Day is a cinematic masterpiece that deserves its place in the pantheon of great movies. It's not just a great sequel but a great movie, period. It has everything you could ask for in a film - action, suspense, emotional depth, and memorable characters. If you haven't seen it yet, do yourself a favor and watch it as soon as possible!

Director James Cameron's sci-fi action-thriller sequel Terminator 2: Judgment Day (1991) may be as good, if not more exciting than The Terminator (1984). I love how moody James Cameron's direction looks and feels. The entire Terminator 2 has a blue color palette that's lovely to look at with bright white lights to illuminate the shadows. Cinematographer Adam Greenberg's wide shots are pretty, but it's his hypnotic close-up and medium shots of Linda Hamilton's pensive Sarah Connor in the quieter moments that look the best. All the angles and perspectives really allow for the new CGI to show off crazy things Robert Patrick's T-1000 villain can do. Terminator 2 looks amazing decades later with effects that are not dated.

Cameron's direction is all killer, no filler with plenty of bloody shootouts, intense chases, and funny one liners. It's basically one long chase sequence as Linda Hamilton's heroine Sarah Connor and Edward Furlong's John Connor are being chased by Robert Patrick's shape-shifting robot assassin Terminator serial number T-1000. His liquid metal body allows for insane bullet soaking and outrageously fun sequences that make him a relentless villain like Arnold in the first Terminator film. Seeing him kill the night shift guard is still shocking and entertaining. Arnold casually tossing people around like The Terminators is really like a logical conclusion to Hal 3000 from 2001: A Space Odyssey if he had a body, complete with red eyes. Terminator 2: Judgment Day is a fabulously crafted film and an exhilarating action-thriller movie for the ages.

There's really clever thought put into the robotic movements, groundbreaking visual effects, and violent action to entertain us from writers James Cameron and William Wisher. That first encounter when you think Arnold's Terminator is still the villain about to shoot John Connor, then he unveils his shotgun from the roses to unload into The T-1000 instead is one of cinema's coolest moments. Immediately, followed by The T-1000 healing and reforming his liquid metal body back to normal after being repeatedly shot. The slick writing for Terminator 2 breaks down the rules for T-1000's morphing due to its poly-alloy into him changing due to liquid metal is very easy for audiences to follow. I love lines like Arnold saying "Your foster parents are dead." It's a clever script with nifty sci-fi ideas for The Terminator, earnest understanding for John Connor, and redemption for Sarah Connor. It's more about humanizing Arnold's Terminator and getting to cool action rather than an original sci-fi concept, but Terminator 2 works.

Making The T-1000 a cop in appearance was deliberate as social commentary on James Cameron's part. John Connor's step-parents blindly trusting Robert Patrick's cop, even though he's a killer, just because he looks like a police officer is brilliant commentary. Every adult and kid just Thinking about how police get away with murder or crimes because of their powerful status in society and position of authority is interesting. It's so funny watching Arnold mess with the cops in T2. Besides the corporation of Skynet producing Terminators as the robots that destroy humanity for profit motives is a neat critique of capitalism. The psychologist not listening to Sarah Connor despite knowing a man massacred the entire police station in the first Terminator really hits home about how flawed the mental health facilities are in the United States. Sarah's "How were you supposed to know?" speech is a brilliant criticism of the ethics of scientific advances that can cause ruination.

Arnold Schwarzenegger is fantastic as the fearsome Terminator. Now even funnier and kinder as he assumes a father figure role for John Connor. Arnold looks cool and effortless as he kills or tosses people around, but it's his serious performance that feels so touching and timeless.

Linda Hamilton is very captivating, pensive, sympathetic, and cool as heroine Sarah Connor. She shoots guns like Arnold and gives a moving and profound performance as a revolutionary against machines, mother to a future leader, and heroine against violent forces. Her narration and expressive acting are remarkable in Terminator 2.

Edward Furlong is likable and funny as John Connor. I appreciate how thoughtful he feels even as a child actor. There's a lot of responsibility on John, and Furlong depicts his conflicted feelings naturally. Robert Patrick is eerie and entertaining as the relentless T-1000. His crazy running and subtle expressions do feel like a killer robot might make them as they search onwards for their dreaded mission.

Editors Mark Goldblatt, Richard A. Harris, and Conrad Buff IV shove violent action scene after scene in your face with a breakneck pace, so you never notice Terminator 2 is 137 minutes long until the credits roll. Production designer Joseph C. Nemec III makes labs, trucks, and factories that look realistic with an industrial feel. Joseph P. Lucky, Charles William Breen, and Gary Diamond's art direction creates striking imagery like the nuclear bomb explosion to the T-1000's endless transformations and injures like he's The Thing. John M. Dwyer and Carole Lee Cole's set decoration has natural 1991 furniture and props, but especially with a gritty industrial look of metal everywhere.

Visual effects artists Dennis Muren, Doug Chiang, Alison Savitch, Janet Healy, Leslie Huntley, Gene Warren Jr., and Andrew Kennedy steals the show with groundbreaking and creative usage of CGI. The CGI does not look dated to me like so many early visual effects done on computers. Having practical miniatures when possible and CGI for when the T-1000 melts down or through objects is pretty creative and balanced. CGI really should only be used sparingly like in Terminator 2.

Composer Brad Fiedel's thudding synth score has beautiful melodies and hectic suspense within his exciting score. Even in 1991, synths in scores sounded wonderful. Sound designers Gary Rydstrom, Gloria S. Borders, Tom Johnson, Richard Hymns, Tim Holland, Teresa Eckton, Ethan van der Ryn, Robert Shoup, Ken Fischer, E. Larry Oatfield, Gary Summers, Kevin Rose-Williams, and John Rotondi come up with all sorts of neat noises. From flesh ripping off the Terminator's arm or the T-1000 transforming from liquid to solid. The nuclear explosion sounds massive.

Marlene Stewart gives Arnold a killer black leather ensemble, but it's Marlene's outfits for Linda Hamilton that impressed me the most. Her black combat gear looks so sexy, practical, fitting, and fashionable on her. Make-up artists Ed French, Jeff Dawn, and Steve LaPorte gave Linda Hamilton neat hairstyles and a nice natural look that makes her stand out.

In all, Terminator 2 is a fun blast and highly influential. You can see in every scene where some other movie found influence for the characters, story, or an action set piece. Think about Mr. Smith taking over bodies in The Matrix and compare that to The T-1000's morphing and impersonations. What a film.

An absolutely amazing and timeless film packed with so much content and heart. This film is the pinnacle of 'intelligent' action and story telling in an action film driven by story and it's characters. A movie that gets so much right; an action movie with purpose. In telling the story and building it's world, nothing goes to waste. Every action, every gunshot, every explosion, every character interaction has intricate value.

The action isn't just eye candy or effects for the sake of it, but an important means by which to clue us into characters, motivations and their capabilities. Two Terminators grappling isn't just a hero and a villain fighting for control, it's the moment our expectations are subverted - the bigger machine isn't necessarily the strongest. As a vehicle sustains damage it only further demonstrates the ruthless persistence of the villain as we see it unblinkingly push aside the wreckage of it's own vehicle the same as with it's own impactful driving. Action with substance, that sells the characters embroiled in in intense action.

This is a movie about humanity. A movie in which Sarah has set aside her own humanity in anticipation and response to a looming machine threat, prepared to do whatever it ruthlessly takes to avert Judgment Day. A movie in which a machine programmed to protect and follow orders begins to understand what it means to be human. And at the center of it is John, a character who finds his purpose and place in the world, taught by Sarah in preparation for the future but becoming the heart of the film and to those around him.

The actors deserve a tonne of praise. Linda Hamilton as the intense haunted Sarah. Arnold Schwarzenegger as the stoic machine becoming the increasingly humanised 'Uncle Bob' figure. Edward Furlong's transformation from a bratty kid to (as stated) becoming the central figure and heart of the film. Robert Patrick's efforts in bringing the sleek efficient cold T-1000 to life, unflinching, unwavering and determined to accomplish it's mission. Even Earl Boen's performance as detestable Dr Silberman makes for a satisfying side-villain to the larger plot.

Perhaps one of the greatest strengths of the movie comes from the fact that (despite it's length) it feels a complete and satisfying experience from start to finish. So much happens during the run time, but it never feels like a slog. An  element T2 Judgment Day does so well is convey the scope of 'what's at stake', managing it's use of threats and obstacles that the core characters face very well - the T-1000 isn't the point of the film in itself, and yet feels entirely relevant even if not present the entire time. 

The movie soundtrack composed by Brad Fiedel is also extremely memorable, providing important flavour for the many memorable moments and for representing the characters, from the metallic heart-beat like clanging sound of the T-800, to the haunting noises accompanying the creepy unnerving T-1000. 

The film is absolute must see and complete experience.

Terminator 2: Judgement Day - 10/10. James Cameron's sci-fi masterpiece celebrates its 30th anniversary this year, and the movie just keeps getting better as it ages. Cameron delivered the cult classic The Terminator in 1984, which ended up launching the careers of himself, Linda Hamilton, and of course the biggest action star the world will soon to see, Arnold Schwarzenegger. So when he decided to do a sequel, 7 years later, a lot of people were wondering how and what he will do. Not only was the sequel the biggest budgeted film of all time till that date, but it upped the stakes both scope and story wise. Never have we seen a small budget film get a huge increase in production for its sequel, but considering Cameron's ascent to mega director status, Carolco decided to take a chance and give the director complete creative/financial freedom. The end result was an R rated, cold and bombastic sci-fi action film that would raise the genre to new heights, and raise the CGI bar even higher (before Jurassic Park elevated CGI to the highest stratosphere possible). T2 is a perfect example of allowing a director to tell their story and allow them to craft it in a way that would really show their flair and trademarks in storytelling. What Cameron did was really raise the bar on the apocalyptic stakes that were introduced in the first film. With the money he was able to literally show the fire and destruction of what could happen if Skynet was able to go with their plans. It really hits you hard as a viewer and makes you understand that this film is not gonna hold back. He elevates the Sarah Connor character, making Hamilton give the best performance of her career as the now jaded and determined Connor, whose screen presence is off the charts. Arnold as the T1000 is amazing because Cameron directs him to his strengths: being a physical mammoth whose cold dialogue delivery matches the robot character. Robert Patrick as the villain is also cool, bringing an agile and malleable threat to the characters. But what I appreciate the most about this film is its message of easing on the reliance of tech. A message that is important to this day than it was 3 decades ago.

It never occurred to me before, but T2 is really an archetypal "A Boy and His Dog" story along the lines of "Old Yeller" or "Pete's Dragon" or "ET: The Extraterrestrial." I'll assume anyone reading this has already seen the movie, so spoilers ahead. Arnold Schwarzenegger was a huge star when this sequel was made, so this time he HAD to be the hero of the film, this time becoming the protector of a young John Connor, who is being hunted by a more advanced Terminator model played to perfection by Robert Patrick with cold animal-like predatory menace. The "Boy and His Dog" story starts fairly quickly, as a young John Connor befriends the futuristic killer cyborg. Connor teaches him tricks (i.e. that car keys are often under sun visors and, of course, "Hasta la vista, baby"), the boy and his pet Terminator save each other at different points in the film, and in the end John has to give his beloved Terminator a sad farewell that's every bit as touching as when the boy  in "Old Yeller" says to his mama "Listen. Old Yeller just saved your life and Elizabeth's, too. And he saved mine and Arliss'. We can't. We don't know for certain. I'll pen him up where he can't get out. A-and then we'll wait. We could not shoot up like he was nothing. Don't you understand?" Or when Elliott in "E.T." tells his pet alien "You could be happy here, I could take care of you. I wouldn't let anybody hurt you. We could grow up together, E.T." And in T2, it's every bit as touching when the Terminator tells John there is another Cyberdyne chip that must also be destroyed, to which John replies, "No, no no!!  It'll be okay.  Stay with us! Don't do it.  Please... don't go --" with tears streaming down his face. So my point here is that you pair the durable "Boy and His Dog" story with wildly exciting and muscular action courtesy of director/co-writer James Cameron (man, do I wish he'd make a straight-up non-preachy action film again ALA "The Terminator" or "Aliens") and strong performances by Patrick as the T-1000, Edward Furlong as the young John Connor, and particularly Linda Hamilton as the fierce and buffed our tiger mom, Sarah Connor, you have a movie that's pretty irresistible. The CGI does seem fairly primitive at times, but most of it surprisingly holds up with the mix of practical and CGI when displaying the T-1000's knives and stabbing weapons. If I did have a complaint upon rewatching T2, it's that the sequel shifted too greatly in tone from the original, relying too much on one-liners and comedic elements. Admittedly, the one-liners are good and the comedy is genuinely funny, but the hard edge of the original is what makes that first film easily the best in the series. Still, sequels of this era had a penchant for radical shifts in tone and story (i.e. "Mad Max" to the "The Road Warrior" or "First Blood" to "Rambo: First Blood Part II"). Overall, although T2 takes a major shift in the direction of family-friendly with the "A Boy and His Dog" storyline, but the characters, story, and especially the action are brilliant and impossible not to enjoy.

For the first time in several years, I watched the entire movie, and from the opening scene to the final credits, there's not a single flaw — nothing to nitpick, nothing to scrutinize. From the epic and memorable performances of Hamilton, Schwarzenegger and Furlong to the expertly chosen and designed filming locations to the mood-inducing and perfectly-complimentary soundtrack, Terminator 2: Judgment Day is a hallmark in moviemaking and a touchstone in modern cinema. Still mesmerizing to watch after all of these years. In the summer of 1991, the sequel was truly an event. And in 2020, it's easy to understand why the subsequent movies simply couldn't come close to measuring up and why they were met with outright disdain from many fans. The franchise should have ended with T2. I still wonder about the potential of a James Cameron-helmed third movie in 1993 or 1994 with the trio of leading actors returning. Commercially, it likely would have been huge. The anticipation and expectations also would have been enormous. But it wasn't meant to be. T2 undoubtedly could never be topped or even equaled. The story was complete. A moment in time never to be duplicated.

The original Terminator is one of the most intense sci-fi/action movies I've ever seen. T2 is not nearly as thrilling and suspenseful as the original. And that's why I found this sequel, which considered to be even superior to the original, slightly underwhelming. The action set-pieces are almost as good as those in the first movie, and due to the the fact that this one has a massively higher budget, the action sequences feel even more well-shot. The visual effects look fantastic, and surprisingly still hold up pretty well. But the problem isn't about the action nor the CGI; it's about the situations and the conditions here that couldn't make me worry about the characters as I should. Even at its climax, the intensity pale in comparison to that's I felt whenever a car chase or a small fighting scene come in the original.

Another issue I have with this movie is that it drags a little bit at its second act. I don't mean it gets boring at all, but it feels a bit devoid and empty halfway through. Maybe better storytelling could have fixed that. I also have a couple of nitpicks, but I can't say they hindered my experience of watching the movie.

That said, James Cameron doubled down almost every single aspect in the story and the characters to make a new extremely taut story that expanded the characters' arc like I've never seen before in any film. The dialogue between the three main characters and even the story itself revealed that the characters, humans or cyborgs, have extra more layers into them. Even the villain is effortlessly well-rounded, and he oozes the impressive development Cameron has made in this world, that of course in addition to the fact that Robert Patrick is quite intimidating and so iconic as T-1000.

There is nothing can top what have been already said about Linda Hamelton's character, Sarah Connor, which definitely deserves its place among the absolute best female characters ever appeared on the silver screen. With that being said, I prefer to praise the astonishing chemistry between Arnold Schwarzenegger and Edward Furlong as the titular cyborg and John Connor, respectively. From the spot-on jokes and funny one-liners to the surprisingly moving and heartwarming scenes the two characters shared, the dynamic between these two endearing characters is simply unmatchable! Furlong is sadly a wasted talent that proved in this movie and American History X that he has a grand range and monumental acting abilities. Here he walked a very thin line between being an imprudent, reckless teen and an innocent child to bring out a likable, relatable, and quite convincing character.

Judgment Day is undoubtedly one of the best sequels ever made, but in my opinion it didn't surpass the original, nor even reach its level. That's in large part due to its relative lack of suspense that's arguably the best merit the original has.
